div1.p: Carter writes about his life and being homesick.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, June 3, 1900
div1.p:
I rec'd your letter & one
from Ned the 27th relt w'h
said you were still with him.
So I send this at a venture to
Washington. I would have an-
swered you sooner, - if I had not
expected you had left for
North River.

I have had been very well this
week - but it has been a
teribly busy one. I took up a
little bit of writing & be-
coming interested in it, it
grew to be more troublesome
then I thought for. Still it
iswas not more than 1 1/2 days work,
but I had to do it in driblets
C1
B29
2
It has been cool & pleasant
this week - with no rain since
Monday - we had 21 rains
last week all hard ones, -
& the work has been, easy
to do, - although there has been
much of it.

I wonder was I born for a life
of turmoil such as I have
led? It is not a pleasant
life to me. I don't think I
know any one who enjoys
leisure more or is more
content with the small in-
terests of home life - yet but little
have I had for some years - only
t since Sept/97 ha at last
3
3
but it seems a great deal longer
than that.

Ned This is the first spring
Ned has ever seen in the coun-
try & the first spring from the
beginning any of them have
spent in Va., They & you left
Chandeleur May 4/9/ - & so must
have reached N. R - about
May 7 - or 8, spring pretty
well advanced then

The Judge has sheared his
sheep I suppose - we need to
do so just after the “cold
spell in May” - about may
15 to 20. What did the boys
think of that.

Ned said that he & Helen
greatly enjoyed your
stay in Washington, &
I know you did.

Don't like cities or City life
myself - but it depends al-
together on the people you
are with & what you have to
do

I will send this with Hen-
ry's letter to N. R. I judge
you will be there by the
time this reaches you
June 7 or 8.

Love to all & whether at Ned's
house or at home
